title: How does the setting affect the plot in Much Ado About Nothing? - Quora

response.answer_text: I agree with Mr. Nathan: it doesn’t have any effect. Yes, every one of the major characters is a member of the elite, and they’re all at Leonato’s estate for the entire play. But this is a play of character (like most of Shakespeare’s plays)— it could as easily be set in England, or in Egypt, or in Venice, or Paris— or nowhere specified. Remember that there was no such thing as a “set” in the way we understand that term in today’s theatre, so the setting really exists in the audience’s minds.

Who says the setting affects the plot of “Much Ado About Nothing”? Are you referring to the fact that most of the play is set in and around the home of the LEONATA, the governor of Messina? That has very little to do with the plot of the play. Most of Shakespeare’s plays can be set in any time and in any location. See Joss Whedon’s film version of “Much Ado About Nothing.”
